title: Conditional Independence
contentHtml: Conditional independence is a fundamental concept in probability theory and graphical models.

theorem.statement: \[P(X, Y | Z) = P(X | Z) P(Y | Z)\]
theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the joint distribution of X and Y given Z can be factorized into the product of two conditional distributions.

intuition: Conditional independence means that given some context or conditioning variable Z, the variables X and Y become independent. This is a powerful concept in graphical models, as it allows us to simplify complex probability distributions.
